title: Having bought a crap generic chinese cafetiere I went back to the trusted brand.
body:
Yes, it is borosilicate glass (pyrex) & tough as nails (mostly)
Yes, Bodum replacement glass is available, but ridiculously it is cheaper in the main to buy a brand new one, ..crazy!

This is what I did, having got a horrible chinese piece of crap that was a design failure with potential to make users sick from ingesting oil & dirty water dripping from within.

I had to return my bodum as damaged, due to amazon warehouse staff clearly having dropped this from a high pallet, ..the plunger had punched through the usually sturdy plastic, whilst the glass remained intact.

The design of bodum has changed, the additional plastic top has a turnaround pouring filter as a secondary catch opportunity for coffee grounds, this is good (my old one did not have this)
BUT, this would have been returned anyway, as my wife bought it after coming back from france where I (husband) was getting up early & making coffee for everyone...

When I got home I pulled out ANOTHER bodum she had bought (a bodum drip coffee for one) that she doesn't use, ...she then bought a load of coffee with ANOTHER drip coffee design mug for one... I will insist that is taken to her office where it will sit unused!

ONE advantage of buying a big bodum though (if you have an instantpot with the sous vide function) is you can set it to 60c & make cold brew using your cafetiere) ..I use a large parfait jar & make several litres at a time, a cafetiere is less messy & contains the grounds better, but i;m not making that every day (it lasts well) ...3 hours is plenty to draw out what you need, any more time & I at least (with my colombian costco coffee) have not seen a difference in acidity / flavour profile change, ...& I have made it same way from 3 hours through to 20 hours brewing time incrementally (FYI, a bit of context for those considering cold brew)

So if you like cold brew, you might want to go large on the bodum!

title: Makes more than enough for a massive mug!
body:
I've had one of these before. I had it for years and used it daily, and one day I noticed my precious coffee was dribbling onto the counter and I realised it had a crack in it. I suspect I'd bashed it, as I'd had it for about 5 years before the crack. After it broke, I tried another cheaper one. It was ok, but just not as good as the Bodum one.

I like a massive mug of coffee, I don't do little cups or small mugs. I even take a mug with me when we visit my in-laws because they have tiny mugs. I took it to Spain when we'd booked a villa for three weeks too. There were three already there, but not as good as this one, otherwise I'd have nicked one of theirs. I nicked a mug, but replaced it with a smaller one and left a note.

The cafetiere has a lovely tight filter which goes right to the bottom of the jug and you rarely get coffee grinds in the coffee you pour out. Another important feature for me is that it's all dishwasher safe. I'm very anal about getting glasses and cutlery gleaming and the same goes for the cafetiere so it's great that it's dishwasher safe. Also, you can just wash the jug separately as it comes out of the holder. My cheaper one didn't do this and wasn't recommended for dishwashers.

Sometimes you really do get what you pay for and this is certainly the case here. If you like your coffee fresh and to have enough coffee for a massive mug (or several small ones) then I would say buy this one. I'm going to have to go and make a coffee now.

title: The one and only classic cafetiere (French Press)
body:
Having tried a different one recently (unbelievably, it had no knob to secure the three plates that you push down on the coffee, leaving these plates unsurprisngly variously up and down the inside of the cafetiere, ridiculous) I have returned to this Bodum.
It is the classic, perfectly-designed, meticulously-engineered, cafetiere (French Press, call it what you will) to make the best of any ground coffee that you put in it. In broad terms, this coffee should be course ground but this will cope with finer grounds if you should put them in. And it has a knob so that the three plates at the bottom push down towards the coffee, as it should.
All of the elements in it are detachable for washing purposes, of course, it functions beautifully, and it looks nice as well.
In terms of quantities of cups from this '8-cup' cafetiere, this will do two standard English-sized mugs (with milk as well thrown in if you want) or around four standard English tea cups.
Anyhow, bizarrely this is cheaper than many of the newer designs that don't work properly, but even if it was more expensive by a long way I'd buy it. If you want the perfect press, then this will give it to you.

Den Kaffee wo ich aktuell nutze habe ich als ganze Bohne geholt und mahlen lassen. Der Geschmack ist fast gleich zu unseren ehemaligen Kaffeeautomaten.

Zubereitung damit ist relativ leicht. Den Kaffee vorher in die Kanne geben. Dann mit heissen aber nicht kochenden Wasser bis etwa unterhalb von der oberen Schelle einfuellen. Dann das Sieb einsetzen aber nicht druecken. (darauf achten wo der Auslauf hinzeigt). Nach etwa vier Minuten kann der Filter nach unten gedrueckt werden. Wenn es hierbei einen Widerstand gibt nicht mit Gewalt druecken. In der Anleitung steht auch drin das die Kanne platzen kann.

So jetzt zu den Punkten wo mir persoenlich negativ aufgefallen sind.
- der Griff fuer die Kanne ist relativ duenn. Ja ich hab als Mann etwas groessere Haende aber ehrlich der Griff ist dreimal so schmal wie von jedem anderen Teil wo ich hier stehen habe. Egal ob das jetzt der Wasserkocher oder irgendwas anderes ist. Also alle Geraete wo mit warmen oder heissen Fluessigkeiten zutun haben sind vom Griff her dreimal so dick. Und bieten mehr Platz zum Gefaess.
- ich wuerde hier auch eine pauschal Warnung geben zur Kanne. Alles wird und bleibt heiss. Das meine ich wirklich nicht positiv.
Das Glas
Die Metallschellen
Das Sieb
Der Metallstab wo das Sieb dran haengt (ja an den besagten Stab hab ich mir schon einige Male die Finger verbrannt... erstaunlich wie lange und wie heiss das Teil werden kann)

Mir ist klar das das Teil keine Isolierkanne ist. Rein vom Design muss doch den Entwicklern davon klar gewesen sein das alle Materialien die Hitze leiten ^^.

Als negativen Abschluss kann ich noch erwaehnen das die Kanne nicht eben steht. Bzw steht spaetesten dann nicht mehr eben sobald das warme Wasser eingefuellt wird. Kann mir durchaus vorstellen das das Metall mit der Waerme vom Wasser reagiert. (hatte auch schon Bewertungen gelesen wo sich das Glas vom Metall geloest hat)

Ja man kann damit recht ordentlichen Kaffee machen. Am Design koennte man sicherlich noch Verbesserungen machen.

title: Bodum no longer a guarantee of quality
body:
I've had lots of cafetieres and several Bodum ones. I still have a 3 cup Bodum here. This new one is nowhere near the quality one would expect of Bodum. They've been cost-cutting and have reduced quality throughout. I guess to try and hit an Amazon price. The claim that this is reduced from ¬£59.99 currently is an utter joke. Check prices elsewhere and you'll see that isn't the case.

The glass is probably fine although I've not used it as I'm returning immediately (others comment that the glass is thinner). Everything else is cheap and poor. Note how there are no RECENT good reviews - hmm.

The frame is thin and there were flecks of the chrome plating on the black handle when it arrived showing that the chrome is already coming off. The end of spring on ours was sticking out (see pic). The spring itself is a dull steel rather than a bright stainless colour. The metal plate at the bottom of the assembly is just a thin plain pressed piece - feels flimsy, looks cheap. In my pictures you can see new and old. The cover on the thread at the end of the spindle is now plastic instead of metal.

Clearly built down to a price. I bought because I thought it was Bodum quality rather than some cheap generic rubbish. Way to go to undermine your brand Bodum.

title: Classic design let down by quality

Once I recived the product, I noticed that the glass just feels than little bit thinner than a few years ago. Not by much but i could notice. The new mesh filter doesn't scrap up to my old one even which has been in regular use for about 4 years. It consistently lets particulates through from one side and I have tried everything to compensate. This filter is also more hazardous. While your washing, if its not threatening to cut your finger then it is definetely tearing up scourer or sponge.

Now, I am lucky because I can still use the majority of my older bodum but I cannot fully recommend this one as you will be likely using the whole piece. At the end of the day the mesh is going to define how nice your coffee will taste, and if it is leaky, then there is no point to it.

It is a shame because it is an elegant classic design that sits well on any table. Come on Bodum, you can do better.

The quality of the construction is definitely well above the cheap versions. The metal mesh filter is far more substantially constructed and will last much longer. The plastic lid is heavier duty. All in all you get what you pay for. I was very pleased when I found this 8 cup version for ¬£15. Good value for an original Bodum. In our local shop they are around ¬£30. I would recommend this to all those who enjoy their ground coffee rather than instant Nescafe. If it is supposed to fill 8 cups they must be very small coffee cups. You get about 3-4 medium sized mugs from a each filling.
